PyCQED: Python Circuit Quantum Electro-Dynamics Package

To be renamed PySCQED: Python Superconducting Circuit Quantum Electro-Dynamics package.

PyCQED is a tool for simulating arbitrary, static superconducting quantum circuits. The package is currently in heavy development, however it currently has a number of features useful for modelling CQED circuits:

  • Generate symbolic and numerical Hamiltonians of arbitrary circuits.

  • Modular parameter sweeping system and extraction of quantities of interest.

  • Circuit-resonator coupling (capacitive coupling only currently).

  • Single qubit Hamiltonian reduction (local basis method).

PyCQED is built on top of the following external packages:

  • QuTiP: QuTiP is open-source software for simulating the dynamics of open quantum systems.

  • Networkx: NetworkX is a Python package for the creation, manipulation, and study of the structure, dynamics, and functions of complex networks.

and four packages from SciPy stack

  • NumPy: NumPy is the fundamental package for scientific computing with Python.

  • SciPy: The SciPy library provides many user-friendly and efficient numerical routines such as routines for numerical integration, interpolation, optimization, linear algebra and statistics.

  • SymPy: SymPy is a Python library for symbolic mathematics.

  • Matplotlib: Matplotlib is a Python 2D plotting library.

Graph visualisation uses Graphviz.

Circuit visualisation will use `SchemDraw <>`_.

Linux Installation

The PyCQED package and its dependencies can be installed locally as follows:

python3 setup.py install --user

In some cases the dependencies of the required packages may not be resolved and the installation will fail. It might help to manually install the dependencies before running the setup script, as follows (on Linux using python 3.x):

pip3 install $(cat requirements.txt)

The Graphviz executables must be installed for the python module to work, which can be done either from the Graphviz website or using your distributions package manager. Ensure that the executables are added to the system path.

Windows 10 Installation

Assuming that one is using Anaconda, using the Anaconda powershell prompt, the PyCQED package and its dependencies can be installed locally as follows:

python setup.py install --user

The Graphviz exectuables must be installed and added to the system path for the python module to work. Currently this doesn’t appear to work out of the box and thus the path is added in src/circuit_graph.py. This might need to be changed depending on how Graphviz was installed.

Quick Start

The best way to get started quickly is to build upon the examples provided in the notebooks/ directory. There are several use cases covered, ordered from simplest to most advanced usage of the package:

  • transmon-example.ipynb: Basic simulation of a transmon qubit, replicating results obtained from a more approximated model of this circuit.

  • fluxonium-example.ipynb: Simulation of the fluxonium qubit reported by Alibaba. The results they obtain are reproduced numerically, including the qubit spectrum, resonator dispersive shift and qubit-qubit coupling energy.

  • averin-coupler.ipynb: Extensive simulations and example of a process for designing a tunable capacitive coupling element for quantum annealing applications. This notebooks make extensive use of parametric expressions to express circuit components in terms of fabrication parameters and to approximate tuneable Josephson junctions. The response of a dispersively coupled resonator is also analysed.

  • resonator-example.ipynb: In depth analysis of a resonator coupled to a RF-SQUID flux qubit. The resonator dispersive shift, qubit Lamb shift and cavity photon-dependent AC-Stark shift are analysed.

  • local-basis-example.ipynb: Here we reduce both a RF-SQUID flux qubit and a Cooper-pair box qubit to the two-level system representation using the local basis reduction technique.

  • jpsq-example.ipynb: Simulations of Josephson Phase-Slip Qubits are performed, demonstrating how certain circuit components impact the tunneling interference physics of this device.

Circuit QED Primer¶

Here we briefly introduce Circuit Quantum Electrodynamics (CQED) for simulating Josephson Junction (JJ) circuits [4, 5].

Transformations¶

Here we discuss the use of mode transformations for making Born-Oppenheimer (BO) approximations and reducing Hilbert space size.

Ising Parameters¶

Here we discuss methods of projecting full circuit Hamiltonians onto simpler Ising systems [1].

How the Code Works¶

Here we describe how the code builds circuit Hamiltonians and how parameter sweeps are performed.

Module parameters¶

The pycqed.src.parameters module defines two classes Param and ParamCollection that are used to manipulate scalar parameters used in simulations and experiments.

class pycqed.parameters.Param(name, value=None, bounds=[- inf, inf], unit_pref=1.0)¶

This class defines the properties of a parameter used in simulations and experiments. It supports upper and lower bounds and the generation of sweeps for scalars.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The utf name of the parameter.

  • value (int float np.float64, optional) – The initial value to set the parameter to, defaults to None.

  • bounds (list of floats, optional) – The lower and upper bounds of the parameter, defaults to [-np.inf, np.inf].

  • unit_pref (int float np.float64, optional) – A prefactor that encode the unit of the parameter, defaults to 1.0.

Raises:

Exception – If the parameters are not accepted types or the initial value is out of bounds.

Returns:

A new instance of Param.

Return type:

Param

This constructor attempts to generate a latex version of the parameter name for use with plots. It uses the pycqed.src.text2latex module for this functionality. The constructor also creates a sympy symbol associated with the parameter. The first character is the symbol and the following characters are subscripted.

The following class attributes are accessible by the user:

Variables:

  • name – The utf string of the parameter.

  • name_latex – A string to be used with latex.

  • symbol – A sympy symbol for the parameter.

  • sweep – The sweep array.

getBounds()¶

Get the bounds of the parameter.

Returns:

The lower and upper bounds of the parameter.

Return type:

list of two floats

getValue()¶

Get the current value of the parameter.

Returns:

The current value of the parameter.

Return type:

int float np.float64

linearSweep(start, end, N)¶

Generates a linear sweep using numpy.linspace with added bounds checking. The sweep is saved internally, and is overwritten by subsequent calls to this function.

Parameters:

  • start (float) – The initial value of the sweep.

  • end (float) – The last value of the sweep.

  • N (int) – The number of points from start to end.

Raises:

Exception – If the argument types are incorrect, or if start and end are out of bounds.

Returns:

The parameter sweep array.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

setBounds(bounds)¶

Set the bounds of the parameter.

Parameters:

bounds (list of two floats, or np.inf.) – The lower and upper bounds of the parameter.

Raises:

Exception – If the bounds are not in the correct format, or the lower bound is greater than the upper bound.

Returns:

None.

setValue(value)¶

Set the value of the parameter.

Parameters:

value (int float np.float64) – The value to set the parameter to.

Raises:

Exception – If the value is not an accepted type, or it is out of bounds.

Returns:

None

class pycqed.parameters.ParamCollection(names)¶

This class uses an array of Param instances and provides methods to manipulate them in useful ways, for example to create multidimensional sweeps and return substitution dictionaries. It also provides an equation system, to allow parameters to be created in terms of others, or to specify inter-dependencies.

Parameters:

names (list of str) – A list of parameter names to create.

Raises:

Exception – If the names are not strings (raised by the underlying Param constructor).

Returns:

A new instance of ParamCollection

Return type:

ParamCollection

The following class attributes are accessible by the user. These attributes are created or overwritten by calls to ndSweep(), except the last, which is created or overwritten by calls to computeFuncSweep() and computeExprSweep().

Variables:

  • sweep_spec – An array of sweep specifications.

  • sweep_grid_npts – The number of points in the current parameters sweep.

  • sweep_grid_ndims – The number of dimensions or parameters being swept.

  • sweep_grid_params – The list of parameters being swept.

  • sweep_grid_c – Dictionary of collapsed sweeps keyed by parameter name.

  • sweep_grid_nc – Dictionary of non-collapsed sweeps keyed by parameter name.

  • sweep_grid_result – One-dimensional array of values (or objects) that result from computing a sweep with the collapsed grid.

addParameter(name, symbol_override=None)¶

Adds a new parameter to the collection if it does not already exist. If it does exist, nothing is reported.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name of the parameter to add.

  • symbol_override (sympy.Symbol) – An different symbol to use than the internally generated one.

Raises:

Exception – If name is not a str or symbol_override is not a sympy.Symbol.

Returns:

None

addParameterisation(name, expression)¶

Registers a parameterisation of the parameter name in terms of symbols returned by getSymbols(). It is allowed to use sympy functions such as sympy.cos in expressions, and also any previously defined parameters. If the parameterisation already exists, it is overwritten.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name of the parameter that is being parameterised.

  • expression (float, int, variable) – A sympy expression in terms of other parameters.

Raises:

Exception – If the argument types are incorrect, ill-formatted, not found, or out of bounds. Also raises an exception if this parameterisation would cause a cycle in the dependency tree of nested parameterisations.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

addParameterisationPrefactor(name, prefactor)¶

Add a prefactor to a parameterisation expression. This is mechanism for implementing unit conversion between parameters if required.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name of the parametric parameter.

  • prefactor (float, int, variable) – A sympy expression in terms of other parameters.

Raises:

Exception – If the argument types are incorrect, ill-formatted, not found, or out of bounds.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

addParameters(*names)¶

Adds multiple new parameters to the collection if they do not already exist. If some or all exist, nothing is reported.

Parameters:

*name (str, str ...) – Arguments list of parameter names to add.

Returns:

None

allParametersSet()¶

Checks if all the parameters in the collection have been initialised.

Returns:

True if all parameters have been initialised else False

Return type:

bool

collapsedIndices(*indices)¶

Computes the indices of the collapsed array for corresponding indices of the non-collapsed array. Should not be used by the user. Will be hidden in the future.

Parameters:

*indices (int, int ...) – Indices of the single parameter sweeps.

Returns:

A single index to retrieve an entry from a results array.

Return type:

int

computeExprSweep(cobj, paramcb, exprcb, spec, *expr_args, **expr_kwargs)¶

Compute an expression over sweep. Use this to avoid regenerating sympy expressions.

computeFuncSweep(func, spec, *fcn_args, **fcn_kwargs)¶

Compute a function over a sweep. Uses the collapsed grid created by ndSweep() internally.

Parameters:

  • func (function) – Function reference to compute over the sweep

  • spec (list of dict) – An array of parameter sweep specifications, optionally created by paramSweepSpec().

  • *fcn_args (variable) – Positional arguments to pass to func.

  • *fcn_kwargs (variable) – Keyword arguments to pass to func.

Raises:

Exception – If the requested sweeps exceed the bounds of a parameter.

Returns:

None

getSweepResult(ind_var, static_vars, data=None, key=None)¶

Get the result of a sweep as a function of one or more independent variables.

Parameters:

  • ind_var (str, list) – The parameter name that is swept. This is the independent variable. If more than one independent variable are specified, the order in which they appear does not affect the returned result.

  • static_vars (dict) – A dictionary of parameters and associated values for which to get the sweep result. The values need not correspond to the actual sweep values used. The closest value found will be used and returned.

  • data (list, np.ndarray, dict, optional) – A data set obtained from sweeping parameters.

  • key (str, optional) – A string corresponding to a key if the optional data parameter is a dict.

Raises:

Exception – If specified parameters are not found, or some are missing.

Returns:

list of swept parameter arrays, the sweep result and a dictionary corresponding to the static values requested.

If ind_var is specified as a list, the corresponding higher dimensional sweep result is returned in a mesh format.

getSymbols(*names, symbol_overrides=None)¶

Generates a set of sympy symbols for use in parameterisation. They are added as independent Param instances. The symbols are returned in a dictionary so that they can be used to create expressions.

Parameters:

*names (str, str ...) – Arguments list, formatted as the parameter names.

Raises:

Exception – If the argument types are incorrect, ill-formatted or not found.

Returns:

A dictionary of sympy symbols with the parameter names as keys

Return type:

dict

ndSweep(spec)¶

Generates a single or multidimensional sweep of parameters in such a way that only a single for loop is required to apply the parameters.

Parameters:

spec (list of dict) – An array of parameter sweep specifications, optionally created by paramSweepSpec().

Raises:

Exception – If the requested sweeps exceed the bounds of a parameter.

Returns:

None

Sweep Grid Explanation

Two version of the sweep grid are created, a collapsed and non-collapsed version. The former is convenient for use with a single for-loop, whereas the latter is more convenient for plotting data. The grids are saved as class attributes sweep_grid_c and sweep_grid_nc respectively, and their format is as follows

grid = {
    param_name1: ndarray1,
    param_name2: ndarray2,
    ...
    param_nameN: ndarrayN
}

where ndarrayN is a one-dimensional array in the collapsed case, and a k dimensional array for k parameters in the non-collapsed case.

Order of the Sweeps

The last entry of the spec list corresponds to the inner-most nested loop, thus the results of that sweep are contiguous in the result of sweeping the collapsed list.

Retrieving Sweeps

If the collapsed sweep arrays are used in single loop, the results can be appended to a single one dimensional array. To retrieve the result of single sweep given constant values of the other parameters, use the getSweepResult() function.

Example

Here we create a three dimensional sweep and show the collapsed and non-collapsed sweep grids.

# Create new instance
p = ParamCollection(["p1","p2","p3"])

# Generate a sweep specification
spec = [
    p.paramSweepSpec("p1",-1.0,1.0,11),
    p.paramSweepSpec("p2",-10.0,10.0,3),
    p.paramSweepSpec("p3",-2.0,2.0,101)
]

# Generate the sweep grid
p.ndSweep(spec)

# Show the collapsed grid
print (p.sweep_grid_c)

# Show the non collapsed grid
print (p.sweep_grid_nc)
paramSweepSpec(name, *sweep_params)¶

Convenience method to generate a sweep specification for use with ndSweep().

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name of the parameter to sweep.

  • *sweep_params (float, int, variable) – The arguments of the sweep generating function.

Raises:

Exception – If the argument types are incorrect, ill-formatted, not found, or out of bounds.

Returns:

A sweep specification dictionary for use with ndSweep().

Return type:

dict

Module units¶

The pycqed.src.util module defines the class Units which is used to specify a unit system for the parameters of the system and to convert quantities between different units.

class pycqed.units.Units(name, system='SI')¶

This class initialises the prefactors used in HamilSpec and can be used to convert between different unit systems. A series of presets are available.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name of the unit system. Can be the name of a preset.

  • system (str, optional) – The unit system to use. Can be “SI” only at the moment.

Returns:

A new instance of Units.

Return type:

Units

convertCurrent(data, old_unit, new_unit)¶

Convert given data between current units.

convertEnergy(data, old_unit, new_unit)¶

Convert given data between energy units.

convertVoltage(data, old_unit, new_unit)¶

Convert given data between voltage units.

getPrefactor(name)¶

Get the unit conversion value for a specific term.

Parameters:

name (str) – The name of the conversion value to get.

Returns:

None

getUnitPrefactor(unit)¶

Get an unit prefactor.

Parameters:

unit – The base unit of the selected system to get, form example ‘A’ for Ampere in the SI system.

Raises:

Exception – If the base unit is not found.

Returns:

The unit prefactor

All prefactors are updated following this call.

loadPreset(preset)¶

Load a preset.

Parameters:

preset (str) – The name of the preset.

Returns:

None

All prefactors are updated following this call.

setCurrentUnit(new_unit)¶

Set the output current unit. The prefix and the unit are detected to determine the correct factor.

Parameters:

new_unit (str) – The new unit to use, for example ‘mA’ for milli-Ampere.

Raises:

Exception – If the base unit or the prefix are not found.

Returns:

None

All prefactors are updated following this call.

setEnergyUnit(new_unit)¶

Set the output energy unit. The prefix and the unit are detected to determine the correct factor. A number of commonly used units are available, such as Kelvin and electron-Volts.

Parameters:

new_unit (str) – The new unit to use, for example ‘keV’ for kilo-electron-Volts.

Raises:

Exception – If the base unit or the prefix are not found.

Returns:

None

All prefactors are updated following this call.

setUnit(new_unit)¶

Set an input unit. The prefix and the unit are detected to determine the correct factor.

Parameters:

new_unit (str) – The new unit to use, for example ‘mA’ for milli-Ampere.

Raises:

Exception – If the base unit or the prefix are not found.

Returns:

None

All prefactors are updated following this call.

setUnitPrefactor(unit, new_unit, value)¶

Set an input unit prefactor directly. This allows specifying units in terms of physical constants.

Parameters:

  • unit – The base unit of the selected system to use, form example ‘A’ for Ampere in the SI system.

  • new_unit (str) – A string describing the new unit.

  • value (float) – The value to set the conversion factor to.

Raises:

Exception – If the base unit is not found.

Returns:

None

All prefactors are updated following this call.

setVoltageUnit(new_unit)¶

Set the output voltage unit. The prefix and the unit are detected to determine the correct factor.

Parameters:

new_unit (str) – The new unit to use, for example ‘mV’ for milli-Volt.

Raises:

Exception – If the base unit or the prefix are not found.

Returns:

None

All prefactors are updated following this call.

pycqed.units.units_presets = {'CQED1': {'A': {'factor': 1e-06, 'unit': 'uA'}, 'C': {'factor': 3.20435324e-19, 'unit': '2e'}, 'Current': {'factor': 1000000.0, 'unit': 'uA'}, 'Energy': {'factor': 1.5091902046963573e+24, 'unit': 'GHz'}, 'F': {'factor': 1e-15, 'unit': 'fF'}, 'H': {'factor': 1e-12, 'unit': 'pH'}, 'Hz': {'factor': 1000000000.0, 'unit': 'GHz'}, 'J': {'factor': 1.0, 'unit': 'J'}, 'K': {'factor': 1.0, 'unit': 'K'}, 'Ohm': {'factor': 1.0, 'unit': 'Ohm'}, 'V': {'factor': 1e-06, 'unit': 'uV'}, 'Voltage': {'factor': 1000000.0, 'unit': 'uV'}, 'Wb': {'factor': 2.067833831e-15, 'unit': 'phi0'}, 'eV': {'factor': 1.0, 'unit': 'eV'}}, 'CQED2': {'A': {'factor': 1e-09, 'unit': 'nA'}, 'C': {'factor': 3.20435324e-19, 'unit': '2e'}, 'Current': {'factor': 999999999.9999999, 'unit': 'nA'}, 'Energy': {'factor': 1.5091902046963573e+24, 'unit': 'GHz'}, 'F': {'factor': 1e-15, 'unit': 'fF'}, 'H': {'factor': 1e-12, 'unit': 'pH'}, 'Hz': {'factor': 1000000000.0, 'unit': 'GHz'}, 'J': {'factor': 1.0, 'unit': 'J'}, 'K': {'factor': 1.0, 'unit': 'K'}, 'Ohm': {'factor': 1.0, 'unit': 'Ohm'}, 'V': {'factor': 1e-09, 'unit': 'nV'}, 'Voltage': {'factor': 999999999.9999999, 'unit': 'nV'}, 'Wb': {'factor': 2.067833831e-15, 'unit': 'phi0'}, 'eV': {'factor': 1.0, 'unit': 'eV'}}}¶

Unit system presets

Module dataspec¶

The pycqed.src.dataspec module defines the classes TempData and ProjectData.

The class TempData is used as a base class to provide functionality on how to save and handle data generated by the classes CircuitSpec, HamilSpec and ParamCollection for memory management purposes.

The class ProjectData is used to create structured output for later use. This is a mechanism for saving work in a consistent way.

This module also defines a series of plotting utilities for data representation, based on matplotlib.

class pycqed.dataspec.ProjectData¶
class pycqed.dataspec.TempData¶

This class is used to manage data generated by the various classes used in PyCQED. It provides a mechanism for saving data to disk temporarily rather than using RAM.

On instantiation the root temporary directory is created in a suitable location determined by the operating system.

clearSessionData()¶

Deletes temporary data associated with the current session. Should be called when an object is deleted ideally, to ensure the HDD is not filled with excessive amounts of data. In any case the OS should automatically delete temporary files at least following a power cycle.

newPrefix(pref_id)¶

A new prefix should be created in association with a particular dataset generated by a PyCQED class. During the lifetime of a class, if it has an associated session, multiple datasets may be generated. A new prefix allows different datasets to be uniquely identified in the temporary storage space, otherwise they will be overwritten using the default prefix. A unique prefix can be generated from the parameters names and values that were used to generate the dataset.

Currently this isn’t necessary as during the lifetime of this class, the part number is incremented continuously, and thus data will not be overwritten.

newSession(obj_id)¶

A new session should be created in association with the lifetime of a PyCQED class. During the lifetime of that class, any temporary data will be written in that session so that it can be later retrieved. This prevents the temporary data from being overwritten if a new instance of the same PyCQED class is created. Using the objects memory address to uniquely identify it means the same directory will be used for that object.

A new tmp directory will be created in the root tmp directory to identify this session, named after the hex representation of the memory address.

Parameters:

obj_id (int) – The memory address of the object obtained using id(my_obj).

Returns:

The path to the tmp directory associated with this session.

Return type:

str

readPart(filename)¶

Read a temporary data file with pickled data contained within.

Parameters:

filename (str) – The path to the binary file to read.

Returns:

The object retrieved from the file.

Return type:

object

sessionExists()¶

Checks if a session exists.

Returns:

True if the current object has an associated session, else False.

Return type:

bool

writePart(data)¶

Write a temporary data file and return its name so that it can be saved for later use. The data is pickled and written to a binary file.

Parameters:

data (object) – An arbitrary python object that must be serialisable.

Returns:

The name of the data file including its path.

Return type:

str

Module util¶

The pycqed.src.util module defines a series of utility functions that are used internally and can be used by the user.

pycqed.util.createSubspaceOperators(m00, m01, m10, m11)¶
pycqed.util.diagDenseH(M, eigvalues=5, get_vectors=False, sparsesolveropts=None)¶

Dense Hermitian matrix diagonalizer. Wraps scipy.linalg.eigh.

Parameters:

  • M (qutip.qobj.Qobj) – The Hermitian matrix to diagonalize.

  • eigvalues (int, optional) – The number of lowest eigenvalues (and vectors if get_vectors is True) to compute.

  • get_vectors (bool, optional) – Whether to get the associated eigenvectors.

  • sparsesolveropts (dict, optional) – A dictionary of keyword arguments to pass to the sparse solver. These are not used here but are included to reduce if statements where the diagonalizer functions are used.

Raises:

Exception – If M is not a qutip.qobj.Qobj instance or is not Hermitian.

Returns:

A sorted list of eigenvalues or a tuple of eigenvalues and normalised eigenvectors (as qutip.qobj.Qobj types) if get_vectors is True.

Return type:

(numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray)

pycqed.util.diagSparseH(M, eigvalues=5, get_vectors=False, sparsesolveropts={'maxiter': None, 'mode': 'normal', 'sigma': None, 'tol': 0})¶

Sparse Hermitian matrix diagonalizer. Wraps scipy.sparse.linalg.eigsh.

Parameters:

  • M (qutip.qobj.Qobj) – The Hermitian matrix to diagonalize.

  • eigvalues (int, optional) – The number of lowest eigenvalues (and vectors if get_vectors is True) to compute.

  • get_vectors (bool, optional) – Whether to get the associated eigenvectors.

  • sparsesolveropts (dict, optional) – A dictionary of keyword arguments to pass to the sparse solver, see the documentation of scipy.sparse.linalg.eigsh for details.

Raises:

Exception – If M is not a qutip.qobj.Qobj instance or is not Hermitian.

Returns:

A sorted list of eigenvalues or a tuple of eigenvalues and normalised eigenvectors (as qutip.qobj.Qobj types) if get_vectors is True.

Return type:

(numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray)

pycqed.util.getACStarkShift(Erwa)¶

Returns the circuit AC stark shift as a function of the average photon number in a linear resonator.

Parameters:

Erwa (numpy.ndarray) – The full eigenvalue array returned by pycqed.src.HamilSpec.getResonatorResponse().

Returns:

The photon number list and the AC Stark shifted circuit energy gaps.

Return type:

(numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray)

The format of the returned array is: ret[q,n] is the gap between the state q and the ground state, at n photons.

pycqed.util.getCircuitLambShift(Erwa)¶

Returns the circuit Lamb shift due to coupling to a linear resonator.

Parameters:

Erwa (numpy.ndarray) – The full eigenvalue array returned by pycqed.src.HamilSpec.getResonatorResponse().

Returns:

The Lamb shifted (dressed) circuit energy gaps.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

The format of the returned array is: ret[q] is the gap between state q and the ground state, at 0 photons.

pycqed.util.getEigenValuesAndVectors(sweep)¶

Convenience function to separate the eigenvalues from the eigenvectors of a parameter sweep returned by pycqed.src.HamilSpec.getSweep(). When the diagonaliser is configured to return both eigenvalues and vectors, the dtype of the numpy.ndarray will be object, which results in conversion issues for example in matplotlib. This function performs the conversion of the numpy.ndarray dtype.

Parameters:

sweep (numpy.ndarray) – The sweep structure returned by pycqed.src.HamilSpec.getSweep().

Returns:

The eigenvalues as numpy.float64 types and eigenvectors as object types contained in sweep.

Return type:

(numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray)

pycqed.util.getExpectationValues(sweep)¶
pycqed.util.getNeighbours(bitstring, HW=1)¶

Generates the nearest neighbours of the given bit string according to the given Hamming weight.

Parameters:

  • bitstring (str) – The bitstring consisting of 0 and 1 characters.

  • HW (int, optional) – The desired Hamming weight, defaults to 1.

Returns:

A list of the nearest neighbours of Hamming weight HW to bitstring.

Return type:

list

pycqed.util.getResonatorShift(Erwa)¶

Returns the linear resonator shift as a function of the average photon number.

Parameters:

Erwa (numpy.ndarray) – The full eigenvalue array returned by pycqed.src.HamilSpec.getResonatorResponse().

Returns:

The Lamb shifted (dressed) circuit energy gaps.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

The format of the returned array is: ret[q,n] is the resonant frequency at circuit state q and at n photons.

pycqed.util.hdot(m1, m2)¶

Compute the Hadamard product of two matrices.

Parameters:

  • m1 (np.ndarray, np.matrix, list) – The first matrix.

  • m2 (np.ndarray, np.matrix, list) – The second matrix.

Returns:

The Hadamard product of two matrices.

Return type:

np.matrix

pycqed.util.isStoquastic(H, order=[2, 3])¶

Checks if the given Hamiltonian is Stoquastic. Non-Stoquastic Hamiltonians are understood to lead to sign-problems in Quantum Monte Carlo methods [3]. We use the permutation matrix representation of the Hamiltonian and the Off-Diagonal Expansion method [2] to find the configurations for which a negative weight exists. There are infinite possible configurations to infinite order. It should suffice to check the configurations of low order, however the order values to check can be specified.

__IMPLEMENTATION NOTE:__ Currently the implementation is inefficient and cannot make use of sparse matrices.

Parameters:

  • H (qutip.qobj.Qobj) – The Hamiltonian to verify stoquasticity.

  • order (list, optional) – A list of order values for which each configuration should be checked.

Returns:

True if the specified Hamiltonian is stoquastic.

Return type:

bool

pycqed.util.mdot(*args)¶

Compute a sequence of dot or matrix products.

Parameters:

*args (np.ndarray, np.ndarray ...) – A sequence of numpy matrices to multiply in the order specified.

Returns:

The result of the dot or matrix product.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

pycqed.util.pauliCoefficients(E, V, basis_op)¶

Performs Hamiltonian reduction to a two-dimensional Hilbert space useful for describing qubits as spins. This function returns the Pauli coefficients \(h_\mathrm{x,y,z}\) of the corresponding spin operators \(\hat{\sigma}_\mathrm{x,y,z}\). We use the ‘local basis’ approach developed by G. Consani [1] which is superior to traditional qubit circuit Hamiltonian reduction methods.

Parameters:

  • E (numpy.ndarray) – A two-dimensional list of eigenvalues, the first index corresponding to the state number, and the second corresponding to the value of a swept variable, usually an external charge or flux depending on the qubit type.

  • V (numpy.ndarray) – The eigenvectors corresponding to the supplied eigenvalues. The eigenvectors themselves should be Qobj instances.

  • basis_op (qutip.qobj.Qobj, numpy.ndarray) – A list or a single operator that defines the computational basis. Usually the persistent current for a flux qubit or the charge number for a charge qubit.

Raises:

Exception – If E and V are not of type list or numpy.ndarray.

Returns:

The list of \(h_\mathrm{x,y,z}\) values for each value of the swept variable.

Return type:

(numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray)

pycqed.util.pickleRead(filename)¶

Read pickled data from a binary file.

Parameters:

filename (str) – The path and filename to read from.

Returns:

The unpickled data contained in the specified file.

Return type:

object

pycqed.util.pickleWrite(obj, filename)¶

Write pickled data to a binary file.

Parameters:

  • obj (object) – A serialisable python object.

  • filename (str) – The path and filename to write to.

Returns:

The filename that was written to.

Return type:

str

Sanitizes an array a by setting values less than tol to zero, including the imaginary component.

Parameters:

  • a (np.ndarray, np.matrix, list) – The input array.

  • tol (float) – The cutoff below which values are set to zero.

Sanitizes a float f by setting it to zero if less than tol, including the imaginary component.

Parameters:

  • f (float) – The input float.

  • tol (float) – The cutoff below which values are set to zero.

[2]

[4]

Andrew J Kerman. Efficient simulation of complex , Josephson quantum circuits with linear inductances. Not Published, 2017.

[5]

Uri Vool and Michel Devoret. Introduction to quantum electromagnetic circuits. International Journal of Circuit Theory and Applications, 45(7):897–934, 2017. arXiv:1610.03438, doi:10.1002/cta.2359.
